We were trying to determine if changing only the velocity of the cart to a new (constant) value would have any effect on the frictional force that is acting on the cart.__MSG_PART_BOUNDARY__ summary.cc.46 11 2015-03-13 09:12:25 Eastern Daylight Time rcart-rq1.summary recipe-479 initiation recipe-479-step2 [continue]We started out with the fact that the velocity of the cart was constant. Next, we used the definition of acceleration to determine that if the velocity was constant, then the acceleration of the cart was zero. Then, we applied Newton`s second law to determine that zero acceleration meant that the cart was experiencing zero net force. From there, we used the definition of net force to tell us that the forces on the cart must be balanced. Finally, from the free-body diagram, we were able to see that the frictional force must be balanced out by the horizontal component of the applied force; and since the applied force was not changed in this new scenario, the friction force would not be affected either.__MSG_PART_BOUNDARY__ summary.cc.46 11 2015-03-13 09:12:25 Eastern Daylight Time rcart-rq1.summary recipe-479 initiation recipe-479-step3 [continue]__MSG_PART_BOUNDARY__ rcart.rq1sem summary.cc.46 11 2015-03-13 09:12:25 Eastern Daylight Time rcart-body recipe-408 initiation recipe-408-step5 [continue]So we are finished discussing the relationship between velocity and friction. Then, we applied Newton`s second law to determine that zero acceleration meant that the cart was experiencing zero net force. From there, we used the definition of net force to tell us that the forces on the cart must be balanced. From there, we used the definition of net force to tell us that the forces on the cart must be balanced.
